name: Kinmedai Nitsuke (Braised Alfonsino)
description: Kinmedai Nitsuke (Braised Alfonsino) is a classic Japanese fish dish gently simmered in a flavorful sauce made of soy sauce, sake, mirin, and ginger.
recipeIngredient: ½ lb kinmedai (alfonsino) ((fillet, rinsed under cold water and patted dry with paper towels))

itemListElement.text: In a medium saucepan over medium heat, bring to a boil enough water to just cover the kinmedai.
itemListElement.name: In a medium saucepan over medium heat, bring to a boil enough water to just cover the kinmedai.

itemListElement.text: Once boiling, place ½ lb kinmedai (alfonsino) in the boiling water. Remember, you do not need to cook the fish here.
itemListElement.name: Once boiling, place ½ lb kinmedai (alfonsino) in the boiling water. Remember, you do not need to cook the fish here.

itemListElement.text: As soon as the fish’s surface becomes white, remove it from the pan and run under cold water. Pat dry the fish with a paper towel. Discard the cooking water and quickly rinse the saucepan.
itemListElement.name: As soon as the fish’s surface becomes white, remove it from the pan and run under cold water. Pat dry the fish with a paper towel. Discard the cooking water and quickly rinse the saucepan.

itemListElement.text: In the same saucepan, combine ⅓ cup sake, 2 Tbsp mirin, 1 Tbsp sugar, and 2 Tbsp soy sauce, and bring to a boil over medium heat.
itemListElement.name: In the same saucepan, combine ⅓ cup sake, 2 Tbsp mirin, 1 Tbsp sugar, and 2 Tbsp soy sauce, and bring to a boil over medium heat.

itemListElement.text: Once boiling, reduce the heat to medium low. Then, add the fish and 2 slices ginger. Place an otoshibuta (a drop lid) on top of the fish and simmer for 7–8 minutes (depending on the thickness of the fish).
itemListElement.name: Once boiling, reduce the heat to medium low. Then, add the fish and 2 slices ginger. Place an otoshibuta (a drop lid) on top of the fish and simmer for 7–8 minutes (depending on the thickness of the fish).

itemListElement.text: Stay around the kitchen to make sure the sauce doesn‘t evaporate too fast. Add a little bit of water if the sauce is low. Spoon the sauce over the fish a few times.
itemListElement.name: Stay around the kitchen to make sure the sauce doesn‘t evaporate too fast. Add a little bit of water if the sauce is low. Spoon the sauce over the fish a few times.

itemListElement.text: Carefully lift the fish onto a serving plate and spoon some of the sauce over the fish. Enjoy!
itemListElement.name: Carefully lift the fish onto a serving plate and spoon some of the sauce over the fish. Enjoy!

itemListElement.text: You can keep the leftovers in an airtight container and store in the refrigerator for up to 2 days.
itemListElement.name: You can keep the leftovers in an airtight container and store in the refrigerator for up to 2 days.

review.reviewBody: This dis is  absolutely delicious and very easy and quick to make. I have used alfonsino and tarakihi  and both worked splendidly.   I serve with crispy crushed potatoes and a Japanese slaw. Thank you for another great recipe :-)
Super easy to make and yummmmmmy!! I love it!!
This recipe was crazy amazing. I've only tried it with the alfonsino, though. If you can get the fish, definitely use this recipe.
